awd_titl_txt: EAGER: DCL: SaTC: Enabling Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Efficient Human-in-the-Loop Redaction of Language Development Corpora
awd_abstract_narration:
At great effort and expense, and with the cooperation of hundreds of parents, teachers, and children, researchers have collected conversation transcripts to study topics like children's language development. The data most useful for science are longitudinal and naturalistic, such as data collected periodically over time in children's homes. Unfortunately, the longitudinal, naturalistic corpora most likely to advance knowledge may contain information that renders participants identifiable. For this reason, naturalistic corpora are rarely shared with other researchers, hindering science. Sharing requires careful redaction--the removal of potentially identifying information. Currently, naturalistic corpora are often too large for manual redaction, and current automated tools both miss critical redactions and over-redact important information. To enable such data to be shared, this project seeks to develop novel computational methods for redaction.

This project's aim is to develop initially automated, human-in-the-loop redaction of identifying information in unstructured text data. First, to better understand key challenges around what aspects of transcripts make participants identifiable, the researchers are conducting interviews with social and behavioral science researchers and members of ethics boards. From these insights, the researchers are developing novel models for predicting what language may need to be redacted and they are designing novel user interactions for leveraging human expertise in redaction decisions. The unique characteristics of conversation transcripts require modeling novel features of language, drawing from natural language processing, psychology, privacy engineering, and linguistics. Because automated methods lack human insights into conversational context for making complex redaction decisions, the researchers are designing user interfaces that summarize how marked language, or tokens, appear longitudinally in transcripts, enabling human coders to quickly make redaction decisions. As a case study, the researchers are applying these techniques to the Language Development Project, a longitudinal corpus of 100 diverse children's development of language. The project is also training students in multidisciplinary research across the computational and social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
When naturalistic conversations are collected and transcribed for research purposes, as is common in the social and behavioral sciences, the resultant transcripts can contain information that makes the speakers identifiable. Being able to identify the speaker(s) runs contrary to the promises typically made to keep research participants' identities private, resulting in researchers being reluctant to share unstructured text data they have collected. In response, this project advanced the science of redacting unstructured text data collected for research purposes.

The project made a series of intellectual contributions to the science of redaction. First, through interviews with 13 principal investigators from the social and behavioral sciences who themselves steward datasets of unstructured text transcripts, the project created a framework of potential identifiers. This framework outlined seven major categories and twenty-three subcategories of information that may need to be redacted, ranging from canonical direct identifiers (e.g., names) to more subtle aspects, such as unique activities and linguistic patterns. In addition, these data stewards described nuanced conceptions of re-identifiability. While some worried about a participant being singled out as a specific individual, others worried about narrowing them down to a group of dozens of potential individuals. All reported already manually replacing or obfuscating potential identifiers before sharing any parts of their corpora, though these manual processes were often extremely time-consuming. Second, the project used both longstanding techniques from the field of natural language processing (NLP) and more recent techniques involving large language models (LLMs) to automatically model parts of the text that are likely to make the speaker identifiable, as well as to suggest similar types of text (e.g., the names of popular fictional characters) that would not enable re-identification and thus should not be redacted. Third, the project also developed a companion series of user interfaces to enable the data steward to efficiently verify suggested redactions and use their unique human knowledge to make decisions about borderline cases. Through comparative evaluation on annotated versions of various datasets, the project showed that the newly developed approach captured many types of subtle identifiers that existing commercial tools miss.

The project also had a number of broader impacts. Most directly, the tool developed during the project is in the process of being open-sourced to support other researchers, especially those in the social and behavioral sciences, in efficiently redacting their own text data. The project also trained students in multidisciplinary research, involving a close collaboration between researchers from computer science and from psychology. Numerous students, including both Ph.D. students and undergraduates, were trained in robust research methods, privacy engineering, and the application of LLMs to aid in privacy modeling. These are skills that are currently highly desired in the U.S. workforce, and multiple project participants have in fact already joined U.S. technology companies.


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Blase Ur
